deliberation: Checked for figurative uses of “words,” possible metonymy for message or ministry, and any symbolic place-names. The verse functions as a straightforward superscription giving genealogy and geography; all terms (words, priests, Anathoth, Benjamin) are literal.

Examined the prophetic formula אֲשֶׁר הָיָה דְבַר־יְהוָה אֵלָיו (“the word of YHWH came to him”) for figurative content. This is a stock prophetic idiom in which an abstract ‘word’ is treated as something that can ‘come’ to a person, combining metonymy (word for message) and personification (the word as an active agent). The chronological details are literal.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to him
vehicle: An abstract ‘word’ that comes to someone
A message depicted as a visiting, acting entity
Movement / agency domain
ground: Just as a person approaches another, a message reaches a recipient; the arrival suggests initiative and encounter
Arrival and directedness of communication
Communication conceptualized as spatial movement
posture: Narrator’s description of Jeremiah’s call experience using conventional prophetic diction
Matter‑of‑fact report that still underscores the authority and initiative of the divine message
Narrative / prophetic‑call context
instances.explanation: The abstract ‘word of YHWH’ is portrayed as something that can ‘come’ to Jeremiah, personifying divine speech and using ‘word’ metonymically for the whole revelatory event.

deliberation: Considered whether the temporal markers are figurative and focused on the phrase ‘when Jerusalem went into exile’ (עַד־גְּלוֹת יְרוּשָׁלַ͏ִם). The city name stands for its inhabitants and their deportation, a common city‑for‑people metonymy with a mild personifying feel (a city ‘going’ into exile).

target: The community of people from the city being deported
vehicle: ‘Jerusalem’ as if the city itself went into exile
A place‑name representing its population and their fate
Geographical / urban domain
ground: The fate of the city is bound up with that of its residents; speaking of the city’s exile succinctly conveys the people’s deportation
Identification of city and inhabitants
Mapping of place onto community
posture: Narrator’s solemn historical marker using compact, evocative language
Underlines the gravity of the event by letting the whole city ‘go’ into exile
Historical reporting with theological weight
instances.explanation: ‘Jerusalem’ stands metonymically for its people, and is mildly personified as undergoing exile, condensing the communal disaster into a single city‑image.

deliberation: Again considered the standard prophetic formula וַיְהִי דְבַר־יְהוָה אֵלַי (“the word of YHWH came to me”). As in v.2, this treats ‘the word’ as an active entity that can ‘come’ to someone, combining personification of the word and metonymy for the whole revelatory encounter.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
target: Jeremiah’s experience of receiving divine speech
vehicle: A ‘word’ that comes to a person
An abstract message spoken of as a visiting agent
Movement / interpersonal encounter domain
ground: Like a person entering someone’s presence, the message arrives and confronts Jeremiah
Initiative and directedness of divine communication
Spatial and interpersonal imagery for inner experience
posture: Prophet’s own report of his call in conventional prophetic language
Stresses divine initiative and authority while describing an interior experience in external, event‑like terms
Autobiographical prophetic narrative
instances.explanation: The phrase portrays the ‘word of GOD’ as an entity that can ‘come’ to Jeremiah, personifying the word and using it metonymically for the full revelatory act.

deliberation: Assessed ‘I knew you’ and ‘I consecrated you’ for metaphorical senses (know = choose, etc.). These are semantic extensions but function here as standard covenantal verbs describing God’s relational choice and setting apart, not vivid figurative imagery. References to ‘womb’ and ‘birth’ are literal. No clear metaphor, simile, or other marked figure in this verse.

Looked at Jeremiah’s self‑description: ‘I do not know how to speak, for I am a boy.’ The term ‘boy’ is likely literal or near‑literal (youth). The phrase לֹא־יָדַעְתִּי דַּבֵּר (‘I don’t know how to speak’) is idiomatic and somewhat hyperbolic—he clearly can speak but feels inadequate as a public spokesman.

instances.english_text: Behold, I don’t know how to speak
target: Jeremiah’s sense of lacking rhetorical ability
vehicle: Total ignorance of how to speak at all
Claim of having no knowledge as an idiom for incompetence
Cognitive‑ability domain
ground: One who lacks skill in a field may say they ‘don’t know’ it at all
Exaggeration of deficiency to express inexperience and insecurity
Use of absolute language for relative lack
posture: Jeremiah’s self‑deprecating protest in response to his call
Expresses reluctance and fear rather than a factual inability
Dialogue / objection in call narrative
instances.explanation: Jeremiah uses an idiomatic and hyperbolic expression of ‘not knowing how to speak’ to convey his perceived lack of competence as a prophetic spokesman.

deliberation: Reviewed ‘go wherever I send you’ and ‘speak whatever I command you’ for metaphorical travel or speech imagery. Here they directly describe the prophetic commission in literal terms; no distinctive figurative expression beyond normal verb usage.

Considered ‘Do not fear before them’ and ‘I am with you to deliver you’ for personification or metaphor. These are conventional ways of expressing protection and presence; no highly marked image (no comparison to objects, animals, etc.). The vocabulary is straightforward covenant reassurance.

Evaluated the anthropomorphic imagery (‘YHWH stretched out His hand and touched my mouth’) and the phrase ‘I have put my words in your mouth.’ The hand language is standard anthropomorphism. The key figurative core is ‘putting words in the mouth’: speech depicted as a tangible object placed physically in Jeremiah’s mouth, symbolizing divinely given utterance.

instances.english_text: Herewith I put My words into your mouth
target: Jeremiah’s reception of prophetic messages to proclaim
Divinely granted capacity and content for speech
vehicle: Placing concrete objects directly into someone’s mouth
Physical insertion as an image for impartation
Bodily / tactile domain
ground: As food placed in the mouth becomes part of a person, so divinely given words become Jeremiah’s own speech
Direct, intimate imparting and internalization of what is supplied
Transfer from giver to recipient resulting in embodiment
posture: Divine assurance that Jeremiah’s speech will be entirely supplied by God
Authoritative commissioning using a vivid, concrete image
Visionary‑symbolic call scene
instances.explanation: Jeremiah’s prophetic speech is portrayed as if God literally puts tangible ‘words’ into his mouth, a metaphor for God directly supplying and internalizing the message within the prophet.

deliberation: Focused on the infinitive chain ‘to uproot and to pull down, to destroy and to overthrow, to build and to plant.’ These verbs describe physical, agricultural, and architectural actions, but here they characterize Jeremiah’s prophetic mission over nations. It is a sustained metaphor of prophetic word as a tool that demolishes and rebuilds.

instances.hebrew_text: לִנְת֥וֹשׁ וְלִנְת֖וֹץ וּלְהַאֲבִ֣יד וְלַהֲר֑וֹס לִבְנ֖וֹת וְלִנְטֽוֹעַ
instances.english_text: To uproot and to pull down, To destroy and to overthrow, To build and to plant
target: Jeremiah’s impact through prophecy on nations and kingdoms (judgment and restoration)
The effects of the prophetic word on political and social structures
vehicle: Uprooting plants, tearing down, destroying and overthrowing structures, and then building and planting
Agricultural and construction/demolition work
Agrarian and architectural domains
ground: Like uprooting and demolishing, Jeremiah’s words will dismantle existing arrangements; like building and planting, they will establish new realities
Radical removal followed by foundational renewal
Processes of tearing down and rebuilding applied to nations
posture: Divine commissioning that magnifies the power of the prophetic word
Presents Jeremiah’s preaching as a decisive, world‑shaping force
Programmatic statement of prophetic vocation
instances.explanation: Physical acts of uprooting, demolishing, building, and planting are applied metaphorically to Jeremiah’s prophetic mission, portraying his words as instruments of both destruction and reconstruction among nations.

deliberation: Jeremiah simply reports his visionary sight: ‘a rod/branch of an almond tree’ (מַקֵּל שָׁקֵד). The figurative significance (pun with שֹׁקֵד ‘watchful’) is not yet stated here but in v.12. Within this verse alone, the language is a literal description of the vision object; the symbolic meaning is supplied in the following verse.

Here the vision of the almond branch is interpreted with a wordplay: שָׁקֵד (‘almond’) and שֹׁקֵד (‘watchful’). The almond rod is a symbolic vehicle for God’s vigilance over His word. This is a metaphor grounded in paronomasia rather than visual resemblance.

instances.english_text: For I am watchful over My word to bring it to pass
target: God’s vigilant fulfillment of His prophetic word
Divine attentiveness and swift execution of promises/threats
vehicle: Watchfulness evoked by the almond (שָׁקֵד) seen in the vision and the verb שֹׁקֵד
An alert, wakeful observer who does not sleep on his duties
Human watchfulness / attentiveness domain
ground: Just as a watchful person stays alert to act promptly, God is depicted as constantly attentive to carrying out His word; the pun on almond/watchful reinforces this
Alertness, readiness, and lack of delay
Vigilant oversight applied to divine faithfulness
posture: God’s self‑revelation in a reassuring explanation of the sign‑vision
Strengthens Jeremiah’s confidence that spoken oracles will surely be fulfilled
Interpretive oracle attached to a symbolic vision
instances.explanation: Using a pun between ‘almond’ and ‘watchful,’ God interprets the almond‑rod vision as a metaphor for His vigilant readiness to perform His word.

deliberation: Analyzed the vision of a ‘boiling pot, facing away from the north’ (סִיר נָפוּחַ … וּפָנָיו מִפְּנֵי צָפוֹנָה). The pot is not about literal cookware but symbolically represents an impending, heated calamity tilting from the north toward Judah. This is a visionary metaphor/symbol.

instances.hebrew_text: סִ֤יר נָפ֙וּחַ֙ אֲנִ֣י רֹאֶ֔ה וּפָנָ֖יו מִפְּנֵ֥י צָפֽוֹנָה
instances.english_text: I see a steaming [boiling] pot, tipped away from the north
target: The coming northern invasion and turmoil that will engulf Judah
vehicle: A boiling, seething pot tipped from the north
Overheated, unstable vessel threatening to spill its contents
Domestic / physical‑danger imagery
ground: Like a boiling pot about to spill scalding contents, the northern powers are about to pour destructive force onto the land
Imminence, intensity, and directional flow of danger
Transfer of domestic hazard imagery to geopolitical threat
posture: Divinely granted image preparing Jeremiah to understand the nature and direction of judgment
Heightens the emotional impact of the coming calamity
Symbolic vision preceding its verbal interpretation
instances.explanation: The overheated pot, tilted from the north, visually and metaphorically represents the intense, impending disaster that will pour down from northern invaders onto Judah.

deliberation: Looked at ‘From the north shall disaster be opened/break loose upon all the inhabitants of the land’ (מִצָּפוֹן תִּפָּתַח הָרָעָה). ‘Evil/disaster’ is treated like something pent up that can be ‘opened’ or unleashed from a direction; this personifies calamity and uses a metaphor of opening a gate or source.

instances.hebrew_text: מִצָּפוֹן֙ תִּפָּתַ֣ח הָרָעָ֔ה עַ֥ל כׇּל־יֹשְׁבֵ֖י הָאָֽרֶץ
instances.english_text: From the north shall disaster break loose upon all the inhabitants of the land
target: The outbreak of invading judgment from the north against Judah
The onset and spread of national calamity
vehicle: ‘Evil/disaster’ that is ‘opened’ from a direction as though released from a source or gate
Something stored or restrained that, once opened, pours out over people
Physical release / flood‑like imagery
ground: Like opening a gate or source so that stored contents pour out, the invasion will suddenly and widely spread over the land
Suddenness, irreversibility, and wide diffusion of the judgment
Conceiving abstract calamity as a quasi‑substance
posture: God’s interpretive explanation of the boiling‑pot vision using vivid, quasi‑material language
Emphasizes inevitability and scope of the coming judgment
Prophetic pronouncement of doom
instances.explanation: Calamity is personified and metaphorically depicted as something ‘opened’ from the north, like a gate or flooded source releasing destructive force onto all the inhabitants.

deliberation: Considered whether ‘families of the kingdoms of the north’ or ‘each shall set his throne at the entrance of the gates of Jerusalem’ are figurative. These describe actual political entities and siege/judgment practices in concrete terms (kings setting up thrones at conquered city gates). Any metonymy (‘throne’ for royal authority) is minimal and functions almost literally here.

Examined ‘they have worshiped the works of their hands’ (וַיִּֽשְׁתַּחֲו֖וּ לְמַעֲשֵׂ֥י יְדֵיהֶם). This is a set prophetic expression where ‘works of their hands’ is a metonymy for idols—artifacts humans have fashioned. It underscores their folly by focusing on the human‑made character of what they worship.

instances.english_text: And they bowed down to the works of their hands
target: The idols to which the people give worship
Man‑made cult objects as false gods
vehicle: ‘The works of their hands’—things they themselves have crafted
Human handiwork presented in place of the idols’ usual designations
Labor / craftsmanship domain
ground: Idols are in fact products of human craftsmanship; highlighting this exposes the absurdity of worshiping them
Identity of object as human manufacture rather than divine being
Using origin (their work) to stand for the object (the idol)
posture: God’s judicial accusation highlighting the irrationality of idolatry
Critically frames idolatry by stressing the man‑made nature of the gods
Forensic / prosecutorial rhetoric
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘works of their hands’ stands metonymically for idols, calling attention to their human manufacture and sharpening the charge of idolatry.

deliberation: Identified the idiom תֶּאְזֹר מׇתְנֶיךָ (‘gird up your loins’) as clearly figurative: it comes from literal belt‑girding before exertion but here commands mental and spiritual readiness. Considered also the verb אֲחִתְּךָ (‘I will shatter/dismay you’) as metaphorical for emotional breakdown, but the primary, marked figure is ‘gird up your loins.’

instances.english_text: But you, gird up your loins
target: Jeremiah’s need to prepare himself resolutely for his prophetic task
vehicle: Physically girding one’s loins by tucking up a long garment for running or fighting
A pre‑action bodily preparation
Bodily / military‑or‑journey preparation domain
ground: As one girds up clothing to move freely and act decisively, Jeremiah must ready himself in resolve and courage for his mission
Readiness, removal of encumbrances, and determination
Transferring physical preparation imagery to mental/spiritual preparation
posture: God’s urgent command, exhorting Jeremiah to active obedience
Motivational and strengthening, yet serious and demanding
Parenetic (exhortational) instruction in the call narrative
instances.explanation: The literal act of girding one’s loins before strenuous activity is used metaphorically and idiomatically to tell Jeremiah to prepare himself inwardly for his challenging prophetic mission.

deliberation: This verse piles up images: ‘a fortified city,’ ‘an iron pillar,’ and ‘bronze walls’ applied to Jeremiah himself. These are three closely related but distinct metaphors all conveying his divinely granted strength and unassailability in the face of opposition.

instances.english_text: I make you this day a fortified city
target: Jeremiah’s overall stability and defense against attack
vehicle: A fortified city with strong defenses
A heavily defended urban stronghold that withstands siege
Military / urban fortification domain
ground: Like a fortified city, Jeremiah will be difficult to overcome despite sustained assaults
Security, endurance under siege, and inaccessibility to enemies
Projecting physical impregnability onto a person’s vocation
posture: God’s encouraging reassurance about Jeremiah’s divinely backed invincibility
Strengthens the prophet’s courage by magnifying his God‑given defenses
Promissory rhetoric within the call narrative
instances.explanation: Jeremiah is likened to a fortified city whose defenses cannot easily be breached, expressing his divinely guaranteed resilience under hostile pressure.

target: Jeremiah’s inner firmness and unbending stance
His unwavering support and stability in his role
vehicle: An iron pillar
A rigid, load‑bearing support made of iron
Structural / metallic strength domain
ground: As an iron pillar stands firm and resists bending, Jeremiah will stand unyielding under pressure
Rigidity, strength, and reliability as support
Transferring mechanical strength to human resolve
posture: God’s portrayal of the prophet as unshakeable in the face of opposition
Intends to counter Jeremiah’s fear of collapsing under pressure
Reassuring, image‑rich promise
instances.explanation: The comparison of Jeremiah to an iron pillar underscores his God‑given rigidity and reliability, presenting him as an unbending support amid opposition.

instances.english_text: and bronze walls against the whole land
target: Jeremiah’s role as a barrier resisting hostile powers in Judah
His protective, separating function and resistance
vehicle: Bronze walls surrounding a city
Thick, metallic defensive barriers
Fortification / barrier domain
ground: Like bronze walls, Jeremiah will stand as a hard, resistant barrier that opponents cannot easily breach
Impenetrability and durable opposition to assault
Physical barrier mapped onto a human vocation
posture: Divine promise that Jeremiah will not be overcome despite being surrounded by opposition
Intends to embolden him by picturing his calling in strongly defensive terms
Prophetic empowerment through stacked metaphors
instances.explanation: By calling Jeremiah ‘bronze walls,’ God depicts him as an impenetrable barrier set against the opposition of kings, officials, priests, and people throughout the land.

deliberation: Reviewed ‘They will fight against you, but they shall not overcome you’ (וְנִלְחֲמ֥וּ אֵלֶ֖יךָ וְלֹא־י֣וּכְלוּ לָ֑ךְ). While Jeremiah does face real hostilities, the language frames opposition to his message in the vocabulary of battle and victory/defeat, extending warfare imagery to encompass broader contention. This functions as a conflict metaphor.

instances.english_text: They will fight against you, but they shall not overcome you
target: Opposition to Jeremiah and his message from various groups in Judah
Social, political, and religious conflict directed at the prophet
vehicle: Combat in which one side fights and seeks to prevail over the other
Warfare with victory and defeat outcomes
Military conflict domain
ground: As in battle where opponents try to overpower an enemy, Jeremiah’s adversaries will strive to overcome him but fail
Intensity, organized resistance, and the notion of ‘prevailing’ or ‘winning’
Mapping military struggle onto prophetic controversy
posture: God’s realistic yet encouraging forecast of opposition framed in martial terms
Assures Jeremiah of ultimate safety and success despite fierce conflict
Consolatory promise completing the call narrative
instances.explanation: Opposition to Jeremiah is cast in the imagery of battle and victory/defeat, portraying his conflict with opponents as a kind of warfare in which, thanks to God’s presence, they cannot ‘prevail’ over him.
